title: Our Chosen Paths
opening: The Kingdom army, having gathered new troops and significant strength, commences its march towards the Imperial capital of Enbarr. In response to their movements, Emperor Edelgard orders her trusted retainer, Hubert, to the front lines to meet the Kingdom army head-on. The two forces clash in the city streets.
With Fort Merceus conquered, it's time to approach Enbarr, the Imperial Capital. Imperial forces stand ready in the city streets, intending to resist to the bitter end.

dialogue.speaker: Gilbert
dialogue.line: Ah, there you are. His Highness was looking for you.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: Where is he?

dialogue.speaker: Gilbert
dialogue.line: He's gone ahead, and started interrogating the prisoner–Viscount Kleiman's man. He said he'd like for you and I to be present as well. Will you come with me?

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: I cannot overlook your reckless remarks. Are you really so keen to lose your head?

dialogue.speaker: Prisoner
dialogue.line: I only did what I believed was right. I swear to the goddess that I'm not lying. Amidst the turmoil of the tragedy, Lady Patricia was supposed to be the only one who was unharmed. We had been given orders ahead of time to not approach her carriage...

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: Was Patricia an accomplice?

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: Of course not. What would my stepmother have had to gain from such a...

dialogue.speaker: Gilbert
dialogue.line: Perhaps Lady Patricia would have done anything to return to the Empire...to her husband and daughter.

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: What exactly are you implying?

dialogue.speaker: Gilbert
dialogue.line: For the past few months, I've been spying on lords who defected to the Empire in order to investigate rumors about Lady Patricia. Cornelia's words were true. The two of them... I am afraid they conspired together, after all.

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: Enough of this nonsense. You say she wished to return home? That isn't nearly enough reason to cause such a tragedy.

dialogue.speaker: Gilbert
dialogue.line: I do not intend to imply that the two of them were solely responsible for the whole affair. There were likely nobles who opposed the king, or potentially someone who wanted to throw the Kingdom into chaos. The Empire, and people like Solon and Kronya, had their motives, too.

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: So my stepmother joined with them to cause the tragedy... Is that what you believe?

dialogue.speaker: Gilbert
dialogue.line: Ultimately, this is just conjecture based on the evidence at hand. I have no idea what their true intentions were.

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: I see. We will hear what this man has to say. For now...

dialogue.speaker: Prisoner
dialogue.line: My lord had long felt that King Lambert's radical ways were dangerous. At the time, he was approached with an offer to take part in the incident at Duscur... My lord loves his homeland. To me, he embodied justice. We were only doing what we thought was right.

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: And so, in the name of justice, he caused massacre upon massacre out of love for his homeland. You murdered your own king, killed our soldiers, and involved innocent citizens. And yet you have the gall to speak of justice?

dialogue.speaker: Prisoner
dialogue.line: I am only standing before you now because I could no longer bear the weight of my sins.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: Did you share those feelings about your homeland?

dialogue.speaker: Prisoner
dialogue.line: Yes... I believe I do.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: Do you regret your actions?

dialogue.speaker: Prisoner
dialogue.line: No. I accept your hatred, and even the punishment of death, but I still believe it was a massacre in the name of justice.

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: Gilbert. Lock this man in his cell.

dialogue.speaker: Gilbert
dialogue.line: Are you not...going to kill him?

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: I will make that decision once I have had time to consider this man's definition of justice.

dialogue.speaker: Gilbert
dialogue.line: Yes, Your Highness.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: Are you OK?

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: No... I cannot say that I am. Tell me, Professor... How well do you remember your father, Jeralt?

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: Not very well.

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: I figured as much. Even the memory of those who pass away is taken from those they left behind. Little by little. Year by year.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: Very well.

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: Soon enough you will come to understand how painful it is to forget the faces of those who have passed on.

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: To be honest, I cannot really remember my stepmother's...that woman's smile. Nor the sound of her voice. I always told myself that I would not allow my mind to forget. And yet...all I can recall with clarity is her gazing away, so forlorn. Did my stepmother wish to go home so badly that she would kill Father and me...kill her false family? Home...to her own blood. Her true family.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: There's no way to know for sure.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: I don't have those answers.

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: I suppose it doesn't make any difference now. I am asking you questions you could not possibly know the answer to. I am finished with thoughts like that. I am finally able to go on living without clinging to hate. If I truly treasure those who have died, then I must earnestly atone for my sins. Father, Glenn, all of the soldiers who have fallen... The people of Duscur who still suffer persecution... The only atonement I can offer them now is to take responsibility for this broken Kingdom that has been entrusted to me.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: That's true.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: Take responsibility for the Kingdom...

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: That is why I feel that I must meet with Edelgard and try to talk to her. Do you think it's a fool's errand? Honestly... I think so too. But I must swallow my feelings and grudges–our whole history, really–and ask her about this future that she sees. What she aims for once her domination is complete. What kind of justice she clings to as she fights. And why she felt it necessary to start this war... I believe that asking her these things is the true responsibility I have been tasked with as king.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: How will you accomplish this?

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: We will march our troops to the Imperial capital. But before any battle begins, we will set up camp nearby and send a messenger. I will tell her that I need to speak with her in a safe place, without any weapons or troops. As to whether or not she will agree to my request... Well, that rests solely on Edelgard.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: I'm certain she'll agree.

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: I would like to believe that as well. You know, Professor... When we fought in Fhirdiad, Cornelia mocked me and called me pitiful. But even if it is true that my stepmother never loved me, I am not to be pitied. After all, I have allies and dear friends who care for me. And now, I also have you by my side.

conversation.speaker: Dimitri
conversation.line: Our next battlefield will be the Imperial capital. There will be no turning back. If you have any unfinished business here, you had best settle it before we depart.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: There's not enough time.

conversation.speaker: Dimitri
conversation.line: I apologize, but you'll have to make do with the time you have. We cannot afford a delay.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Leave it to me.

conversation.speaker: Dimitri
conversation.line: I knew I could count on you. Good luck.

conversation.speaker: Dedue
conversation.line: I believe in you, but please ensure that his Highness survives as well. Fódlan's future would be in peril if we lost him. I would not be able to go on.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Leave it to me.

conversation.speaker: Dedue
conversation.line: Thank you,

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I understand.

conversation.speaker: Dedue
conversation.line: Good.

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: He intends to speak to the emperor? She's his stepsister, I know, but this seems risky.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It's important.

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: Pah! I know that!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: You're against it?

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: No, I'm not. I'm sure he's thought it through.

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: If the two can settle this diplomatically, that would be the best way out of this mess. No more bloodshed. Let's just hope he doesn't become so overwhelmed with emotion that he's unable to strike her down... should the need arise.

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: Returning to the monastery brings back so many memories from five years ago. Hard to believe we only spent a year together here. So much happened that it felt a lot longer than that. But it was so exciting. And so much fun. Honestly, I think those memories are what's kept me fighting this long. What was that year like for you, Professor?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It was a lot of fun.

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: I don't think I could ask for a better answer.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It was challenging.

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: Ah...yeah, there were a lot of hard times too.

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: Let's all do our best to survive this, so we can come back here when it's all over. I know that's what I'll be doing.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: I've been thinking about how we've got our own ideas about justice...and so does the Empire. And what's coming, it's not just a battle between us and them. It's our ideals that are fighting. Whoever wins will say they were right and the other side was wrong. And I get it. That's how it goes... But nobody's willing to talk or compromise, so we'll fight to the death to prove the other guy's wrong. It won't be an easy battle, but let's make sure we come back alive. Right, Professor?

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: We'll be heading for the capital soon. So much rests on this moment. Will the war really be over if we take the capital?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It might not end right away.

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: You're probably right...but we'll get there eventually.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Definitely.

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: Yay! I'm sure it won't end right away, but that's still great news!

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: I truly believe that a peaceful future is waiting at the end of all this.

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: I hope this is the final battle. Don't you, Professor? When the war is over, everyone will be busy with their own lives... But let's all meet up again someday. Right here at Garreg Mach. You, His Highness, my father, our monastery friends, the knights...everyone!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: That's a great idea.

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: It was just a silly whim I had, but I really love it!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I wonder if that's possible...

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: All that matters is whether we choose to make it happen. I really hope that we do!

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: Ooh, and I'll bake a bunch of desserts for it! Reunion sweets! All we have to do now is win! Let's get to it, Professor!

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: I'm so glad you were assigned to the Blue Lion House, Professor. We made it this far thanks to your guidance and leadership. There's a bitter fight ahead - that much is certain. You have my lance.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: We're counting on you.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: We will prevail!

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: Yes. Let's do this together!

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: Professor. At last, the end is nigh. I love the Empire. Part of me wants it to survive. But I know that is not reasonable. The Empire's time has come. The Kingdom is battle-scarred, the Alliance is in tatters... People must be terrified. The world is crumbling around them. What we need now is a mighty leader who can rebuild Fódlan and rule it as a single nation. Nonetheless, it saddens me that we will not have an Adrestian emperor...

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: When you think of it, as one approaches the end of a war, the sacrifices only grow larger, don't they? The winning side musters their forces and attempts to strike a decisive blow... While those of the losing side make desperate attempts to turn the war in their favor. Neither side will give. I only wish we'd consider those who lose their lives in that struggle.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: We're far from being safe ourselves.

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: Yes, exactly my point. Let's be careful to ensure we don't lose our lives, Professor.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It's a necessary sacrifice.

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: Perhaps, but that doesn't make it any easier to accept your own survival depends on a throw of the dice.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It's better than dragging the war out.

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: I can appreciate that, but just because a choice is better does not mean that it's good.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: It's such a relief that we've made it this far without having to fight my father.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: You'll have to face him at some point.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: Are you trying to scare me? What if he turns up while we're charging the capital?!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It sounds like you're scared.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: You bet I'm scared! The Imperial army hasn't lost a single battle with my father on the field!

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: But still, I wonder what'll happen to him if we win...

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: Professor! My, um, mother might be in the city. I don't have many good memories of her if I'm being honest, but she's dearer to me than my father, If you happen to see her, please make sure she's not caught up in all the fighting. She's only a civil servant, so hopefully she takes a cue from her Bernie and stays inside.

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: I keep thinking the war is near its end, then it isn't... When can we finally put this dreadful war behind us?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Let's end it with the next battle.

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: That would be wonderful. Imagine, the last moment of combat...then peace. It sounds like a fairy tale. I want to make this a world where there is no fighting, where children can grow up happy and safe.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: There can be no end to war.

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: I suppose you're right... But we should still try to make the world a place where children can grow up happy and safe.

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: Five years ago... Edelgard said a thing to me. Brigid is a vassal of the Empire. But she also said I always have the freedom to be choosing whether I am with or not with her. I will become the ruler of Brigid. So she said I must make my own path. So now, my path and her path will be colliding.

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: At last we've come to the final confrontation! Ruin to the Empire! Glory to Faerghus! Of course, to be perfectly honest, I would have much preferred to march against the Empire at the head of the Alliance. But I suppose I have Claude to thank for denying me that satisfaction, don't I?

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: We're heading up to Enbarr next. I hope I make it back safe so I can tell my little sis about it! I hear they got a neat opera house there where Manuela used to perform. What was it called again?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Mitreflanc Opera Company

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: Nah, that doesn't sound right!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Mittelfrank Opera Company

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: Ah, that's the one!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Mildewplank Opera Company

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: Nah, that doesn't sound right!

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: My little sis always goes on about how much she'd like to see them perform. I know we can't see a show, but do you think we could at least see the building?

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: We're about to put the finishing touches on this war. I wonder how Fódlan will look without the backdrop of death and destruction. I can't wait to see it! On the other hand, I'm terrified of what the future might hold. Who knows if I'll survive the assault on the capital?

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: Wanting so desperately to speak with Edelgard just as we're about to fight... Could it be that the prince is having doubts about killing her.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I don't think so.

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: Then perhaps it is okay.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: It's only a formality.

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: I suppose they're the only ones who fully understand the extent of their relationship.

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: He's certainly changed from the vengeful person he once was. I don't mean that in a bad way. I'm actually relieved. A king who's responsible for Fódlan's future can't exact personal vendettas and have a cold heart.

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: Dear Goddess...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Praying again?

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: Yes... I was praying for your safety.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: What are you praying for?

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: Um...for your safety.

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: I'll do all I can to survive, but please...please don't die out there Professor.

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: Fighting in the capital! Ugh! And we're fighting against Edelgard! Double ugh! But with you leading us, Professor, I know we'll win. Yeah! Wahoo! Fighting! I'm a little scared, to be honest. I'm just shouting to relieve the tension, but I'll be fine.

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: At last, it's time to face the Flame Emperor... Edelgard. I know that the future of all Fódlan rests on this battle. Nothing else is more important. But for me, this is personal. For Captain Jeralt's sake, I'm going to give it all I've got and more!

conversation.speaker: Seteth
conversation.line: Rhea will be somewhere in the city. I wonder if she can sense us coming. The battle will soon be upon us. Let us both be at our best for what is to come.

conversation.speaker: Flayn
conversation.line: I was born in Enbarr. My mother and father met in the church there. Not too long after, I was brought into the world. I do not understand how war can happen in such a precious place. It is most regrettable.

conversation.speaker: Hanneman
conversation.line: Enbarr's streets are paved with unhappy memories, Professor. I've avoided the damned place since I abandoned my nobility. Swore never to return. Now here we are. To return in this manner... Well, I can't say it is something I ever imagined. Especially as I'm returning to end the Empire. What a strange feeling, breaking one's history.

conversation.speaker: Manuela
conversation.line: Life can be tough, you know? But if you've got your friends to help you through, it can be a lot easier. Maybe you butt heads sometimes...but that's OK. That's how you build bonds, right? And I've got friends, Professor. Plenty of those. It's true love that seems to have passed me by.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: You should relax.

conversation.speaker: Manuela
conversation.line: Relax? I'm relaxed.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: There's still hope.

conversation.speaker: Manuela
conversation.line: But where is my true love to be found? Where is my ray of hope?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Time to give up?

conversation.speaker: Manuela
conversation.line: Yeah... I'm starting to figure that's the most realistic option.

conversation.speaker: Manuela
conversation.line: At this point, I'm just hoping you stay single too. Then at least we can share each other's misery!

conversation.speaker: Gilbert
conversation.line: It matters not how just our cause may be. In the end, war is nothing more than organized murder. I understand the desire to reach a conclusion, but we mustn't overlook the sins inherent in our deeds.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I am well aware.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I understand, of course.

conversation.speaker: Gilbert
conversation.line: Heh, sorry, I have a tendency to preach. We have lost so much, and in return, we have taken much from our enemies. I pray we can put an end to this cycle of violence.

conversation.speaker: Alois
conversation.line: Here we are, facing the final battle with the Empire. It's been a long, difficult struggle. We have to get Lady Rhea back! And we have to crush the Empire, in the name of Captain Jeralt. He's watching over us now, protecting us. I know he is.

conversation.speaker: Catherine
conversation.line: Looks like we're nearing the end of this struggle. I'm sure Lady Rhea is on tenterhooks waiting for me to swoop in and rescue her.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Probably.

conversation.speaker: Catherine
conversation.line: I was just kidding! Pay me no mind.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I doubt it.

conversation.speaker: Catherine
conversation.line: Oof... You don't mince your words. Try being a bit more mindful of other people's feelings.

conversation.speaker: Catherine
conversation.line: Lady Rhea is not waiting for me, I know, no matter how much I might wish she were. She's waiting for you.

conversation.speaker: Shamir
conversation.line: Ten years ago, Dagda and Brigid attacked the Empire from the west. Their final target was the capital. But they were countered at a port town, long before they reached their destination. We spent a lot of time going back and forth, but at least we made it this far.

conversation.speaker: Cyril
conversation.line: Whenever I think about how we'll be seeing Lady Rhea real soon, I get happy and really get cleaning! We'll get there for sure, right? We'll see her again?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: We'll meet her for sure.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: We don't know for sure.

conversation.speaker: Cyril
conversation.line: I just gotta believe Lady Rhea is waiting for us in the capital... We just have to find her.

conversation.speaker: Anna
conversation.line: Seems like the war is gonna end soon. Once the dust settles, it'll be back to rolling in fat stacks of gold for me!

conversation.speaker: Gatekeeper
conversation.line: Greetings, Professor! Nothing to report! Momentum's really picking up for this final battle, huh? Even I'm starting to feel tense! Me! Enbarr's history goes back 1,400 years. That even predates the founding of the Empire. It's one of the sacred sites of the Seiros faith, so it's a pretty big deal. But hey, no need to worry about the monastery while you're fighting the final battle. I've got it covered! I'll defend it to my last!

intro.speaker: Edelgard
intro.line: I...I remember now. You gave me a dagger, all those years ago.

intro.speaker: Dimitri
intro.line: Heh, I'm still sorry about that. I should have given you something that would've made you happier.

intro.speaker: Edelgard
intro.line: Perhaps. At the time, I was quite flustered by such a dangerous gift. I left without giving you a proper response...and that was the last time we saw each other.

intro.speaker: Dimitri
intro.line: True. It is a sweet memory with a bitter ending.

intro.speaker: Edelgard
intro.line: I'm afraid it will do no good to reminisce, Dimitri. That girl you knew back then is gone. As good as dead. But...I'll tell you now what I wasn't able to tell you back then. Thank you. My dear, forgotten friend...because of you, I never lost my heart. As for the future...that will be decided in battle. King of Faerghus. As the emperor, I shall await your arrival in Enbarr.

flashback.speaker: Dimitri
flashback.line: El! So it's true... You're really going away? Going back home?

flashback.speaker: Edelgard
flashback.line: There's nothing I can do about it. It's all happening so fast... I'm as surprised as you are.

flashback.speaker: Dimitri
flashback.line: El... Um... Here. I want you to have this.

flashback.speaker: Dimitri
flashback.line: El, listen to me. No matter how hard things get, you can't give in, OK? You've got to cut a path to the future you wish for, no matter what.

flashback.speaker: Edelgard
flashback.line: It's...a dagger? Why would you give me something like this?

flashback.speaker: Dimitri
flashback.line: Oh, um... I'm sorry. I couldn't think of anything better to give you.

flashback.speaker: Lord Arundel
flashback.line: Edelgard! What are you doing? It's time to go. Hurry and get in the carriage.

flashback.speaker: Edelgard
flashback.line: Oh! I... I'm sorry, Uncle! I have to go now... Good-bye, Dimitri.

battle.speaker: Dimitri
battle.line: The gates to the Imperial capital have been broken. All troops, storm in! The emperor is within reach!

battle.speaker: Gilbert
battle.line: The Imperial troops are dug in across the city. Let's cut through them, and carve a route to the palace.

battle.speaker: Hubert
battle.line: Heh. The Savior King arrives, hands red with blood. Let's give him a royal welcome. Artillery, once the enemy is in range, fire at will. Reinforcements will fly in shortly. Keep your focus and hold steady until they arrive.

battle.speaker: Dorothea
battle.line: Reinforcements should be here soon. Let's draw them in... just like we planned.

battle.speaker: Hubert
battle.line: Draw them toward the opera house. Reinforcements will be here any moment.

battle.speaker: Manuela
battle.line: Has it really been so long since I was in that opera house? Couldn't have imagined any of this back then.

battle.speaker: Dorothea
battle.line: The battle is nearing the opera house. I hope everyone in the company is safe.

battle.speaker: Flayn
battle.line: That church... It looks familiar. I believe that is where my parents first met.

battle.speaker: Seteth
battle.line: Ah—that church. I've such memories of that place. From a time before I was Seteth...

battle.speaker: Thief
battle.line: War is for the wealthy. We don't even have enough to eat... I'm sure the goddess won't punish us for a little bit of thievery here and there...

battle.speaker: Dimitri
battle.line: More reinforcements, eh? And this time it looks like a fair number... It would be best if we could take them down from a safe distance... Is there any way we could neutralize the cannons or catapults?

boss.speaker: Petra
boss.line: Edelgard... I will not be keeping my promise... Give me forgiveness, please...

boss.speaker: Hubert
boss.line: It's almost a shame to kill you. Not even death will make you consequential.

boss.speaker: Hubert
boss.line: I should have disposed of you a long time ago. I will rectify that failure here!

boss.speaker: Hubert
boss.line: Running into you in the capital like this-I have to say it's almost sentimental.

boss.speaker: Hubert
boss.line: You really think you can make her?

boss.speaker: Ferdinand
boss.line: It does not matter what I think. Those are my orders.

boss.speaker: Dimitri
boss.line: Hubert. I would tell you to get out of my way, but I highly doubt that you would abide.

boss.speaker: Hubert
boss.line: Heh. Your silver tongue will do you no good here. This is not your path to tread.

boss.speaker: Dimitri
boss.line: That is not your decision to make, nor is it mine. All I can do is blaze ahead!

end.speaker: Hubert
end.line: We must place our faith...in Her Majesty... Her victory is everything...

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: It's over... The way to the palace is clear. Let's move!

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: Send your platoons to capture Enbarr! There is to be no needless killing or pillaging, understand?

end.speaker: Kingdom General
end.line: Yes, Your Highness!

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: Edelgard awaits us. We will advance our main forces straight to the palace.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: We've finally made it here.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: We can win this.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: Yes, it has truly been a long war. And we have only made it this far because of you... Actually, no. I will save that sentiment for after we win this battle. We will advance our troops and confront her. We must strike down the emperor and end this war.

end.speaker: Dedue
end.line: My life is yours, Your Highness.

end.speaker: Annette
end.line: Let's win this and go back home in victory! I'll do the very best I can!

end.speaker: Ingrid
end.line: On my honor as a knight...I will not lose!

end.speaker: Mercedes
end.line: I know the goddess is watching over us. Let's be sure to return home safely. All of us.

end.speaker: Ashe
end.line: As a citizen of Faerghus, I will fight with everything I have!

end.speaker: Sylvain
end.line: Heh heh heh, is this what a do-or-die situation looks like? You had best give it your all too, General.

end.speaker: Felix
end.line: The path to the emperor is open. Fulfill your duty as our king.

end.speaker: Felix
end.line: Go and win. Be the boar you are, and don't you dare look back.

end.speaker: Byleth
end.line: Let's go!

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: Yes. I will... No. We will win this. Together! Everyone! Move out!

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: The time has nearly come.

end.speaker: Imperial General
end.line: Yes, the anomaly should present itself shortly. However...

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: There's no reason to fret. Besides, it's far too late to second guess. Now, assume your position. I can't promise your safety if you remain here.

end.speaker: Imperial General
end.line: Very well.

end.speaker: Edelgard
end.line: Ugh... This pain is nothing...compared to what I have already suffered...
